title: Senate, House Pass $2.1 Billion Spending Bill to Upgrade Capitol Security, Aid Afghan Refugees
sub_head: Vote drew broad support among Democrats and Republicans after bipartisan negotiations
body:
WASHINGTON—The Senate and House voted overwhelmingly to pass a $2.1 billion supplemental spending bill to fund Capitol security upgrades and pay for emergency aid to resettle Afghan refugees who worked alongside U.S. troops.
The bill, which passed the Senate 98-0 and the House 416-11, was the product of bipartisan negotiations between Sen. Patrick Leahy (D., Vt.), the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, and Sen. Richard Shelby of Alabama, the panel’s top Republican.
Lawmakers said the additional resources were urgently necessary to pay costs incurred from the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by supporters of then-President Donald Trump, and to ensure the U.S. doesn’t abandon its partners in Afghanistan as American troops withdraw.
In all, the bill will designate more than $520 million to reimburse the National Guard for its deployment to the Capitol after Jan. 6, $100 million for Capitol Police, $300 million for Capitol security measures such as hardening windows and doors and installing new cameras, $42 million to cover Congress’s Covid-19 costs and $1.1 billion to help resettle Afghans.
Mr. Leahy estimated that the legislation will result in 8,000 new Afghan Special Immigrant Visas with changes to the program to improve efficiency.
